guide.title: Gentoo Linux Documentation Policy
guide.abstract: This guide explains the current Gentoo Documentation Policy.

body.p: The Gentoo Linux Documentation team aspires to create exceptionally professional documentation that is immediately clear and concise to the end user. In order to fulfill this goal, we have very specific rules and guidelines that all documentation must go through before it is published on our website, or otherwise.
This policy will cover these topics:
Before continuing, it is expected that all documentation developers be subscribed to the gentoo-doc@gentoo.org mailinglist, and that they are readily available in #gentoo-doc at all times.
Additionally, some functional definitions are needed in order to specifically outline the duties and responsibilities of the documentation team.

Official Gentoo Linux Documentation is simply defined as any documentation that is released by Gentoo Linux for consumption by the end user. The only exceptions to this are the Gentoo Weekly Newsletter, and the gentoo.org website, which are maintained by their own respective teams.
Gentoo Linux Documentation can be separated into two categories, critical and non-critical documentation.
Critical Documentation is defined as any documentation that is directly involved with the installation and base configuration of any Gentoo Linux system. To date, our critical documents are:

ul.li: All of the Gentoo Linux Installation Guides

body.p: Non-critical documentation includes all documentation not specifically defined as Critical Documentation.
The Gentoo Linux Documentation team is split into three teams that operate in complete cooperation with eachother. The Documentation team is divided into these three categories:

Technical Writers: The technical writers' function is to completely document every aspect of Gentoo Linux. The writers will periodically be given assignments by the Senior Developers, and those assignments are to take precedence over any other Gentoo Linux development work. Although the writers' work is ultimately proofed by the Editing Team, the writers will still proof their own work before submitting it to the gentoo-docs-review@gentoo.org mailing list and the Editing Team All technical writers must be subscribed to the gentoo-docs-review@gentoo.org mailing list.

Editors/ Proofreaders: The editors are in charge of editing and proofing all changes to the Gentoo Linux Documentation. No change can be made unless it is verified to be grammatically and syntactically correct by an Editor. The Editors must make absolutely sure that all documentation going live on the website is as professional and grammatically correct as possible. All Editors must be subscribed to the gentoo-docs-review@gentoo.org mailing list.

Translators: Due to the special nature of translations, the translators are broken into their own team. Each language will have a lead Developer which will serve as the Editor and CVS publisher. Once the lead translator has deemed that a translation is ready to go live on the documentation index page, they may add it. After the translation is added, a notice must be sent to the gentoo-docs-review@gentoo.org mailing list.

The English developer's job is extremely important, as all translations have their roots in our English documentation. So, it is imperative that the process described below is followed quite pedantically.
If not done already, the following documents need to be read before continuing:
The Gentoo Linux Documentation process can be broken down into several parts:

The first step to submitting a new document or changing an existing document is filing a bug on our Bug System. This serves as a notification to other developers and users alike that there is a work in process. If there is already a bug in the database that requests a change to the documentation, a new bug does not have to be filed.
When the proposed new document or change is completed, two courses of action can be taken:

If the change/ bugfix is technical in nature, the revised document, along with its associated bug number, must be posted to the gentoo-docs-review@gentoo.org mailinglist for technical review. This step is incredibly important, as it ensures the technical accuracy of our documentation. The document in question cannot be committed to CVS unless it is submitted for review.
If the change/ bugfix is grammatical or syntactical in nature, all that is needed is a short note to gentoo-docs-review@gentoo.org stating the bug number if applicable, and the fix.
Once the document is in CVS, a Senior Developer will be notified, and the Document will be posted to the live document index page.
Translators will follow the English Developer's QA process, but with the following exceptions:

Each language will have a translation team, with an Offical Gentoo Linux Translator as their head. All translations will be filtered through this lead person. The lead translator will make certain that the translated documents are grammatically and syntactically perfect. The lead translator will have limited CVS access which will enable them to commit documents in a timely manner.
If not done already, the following documents need to be read before continuing:
The translator's QA process is as follows:

The first step to submitting a new document or changing an existing document is filing a bug on our Bug System. This serves as a notification to other developers and users alike that there is a work in process. If there is already a bug in the database that requests a change to the documentation, a new bug does not have to be filed.

When the proposed new document or change is completed, a notification is to be sent to the translation lead, and the translation lead is to make positively sure that the translated document is perfect in every way.
Once the document and or change is carefully edited by the lead translator, it can be moved into CVS.
Once the document is in CVS, a Senior Developer will be notified, and the Document will be posted to the live document index page.
